review.title: Narrative based Postdictive Reasoning for Cognitive Robotics
review.abstract: Making sense of incomplete and conflicting narrative knowledge in the presence of abnormalities, unobservable processes, and other real world considerations is a challenge and crucial requirement for cognitive robotics systems. An added challenge, even when suitably specialised action languages and reasoning systems exist, is practical integration and application within large-scale robot control frameworks.

metadata.title: Narrative based Postdictive Reasoning for Cognitive Robotics

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: Researchers in the field of thinking about action and change have interpreted narratives in various ways and differ in the richness of their semantic characterization and the formal properties resulting from it (Miller and Shanahan 1994; Pinto 1998), (Mueller 2007), (McCarthy and Costello 1998; McCarthy 2000). For example, narratives are interpreted in the context of formalisms such as situational calculation and event calculation as "a sequence of events about which we may have incomplete, contradictory, or false information" (Miller and Shanahan 1994; Pinto 1998). The interpretation of narrative knowledge in this paper relies in particular on these characteristics, especially with regard to the representational and thinking tasks that arise during the modeling of the perceptibly grounded, narrativated epistemic state of an autonomous agent. In this paper, we deal in particular with large-scale cognitive robotic systems, in which symbolic planning and control at the highest level of an autonomous agent's subcomponents determine the most autonomous status and composition.

sections.heading: Approximate Epistemic Planning as ASP
sections.text: We choose HPX as the theoretical basis for our framework because it provides native and elaborate support for postdictory thinking along with low computational complexity (the plan existence problem is in NP).For alternative PWS-based formalisms, plan existence is a problem that relies dynamically on its knowledge base, e.g. (Baral, Kreinovich, and Trejo 2000).2The advanced plan system uses the online ASP rationality oclingo (Gebser et al. 2011a), which applies its knowledge base according to the sensitization outcomes. To get the most out of our knowledge, no other implemented formalism supports postdiction in this complexity class. Support for postdiction is critical to realize abnormal and explanation-based error tolerance in robotic systems: If sensing shows that the effect of an action is not intended, then postdiction can be used to explain the reason for failure.

sections.heading: Narrativised Online Robot Control
sections.text: The original h-approximation formalism and planning system is designed for offline problem solving, i.e., a conditional plan is created and the projected future world states are checked to see if a predefined goal holds. In this work, we extend the h-approximation so that it is able to plan online and provide abductive explanations. In addition, we define several measures for assessing the quality of a plan (e.g. robustness in the face of unknown contingencies). An essential feature of the h-approximation is support for the shift; we use the shift to find explanations of why an action was successful or not. We propose to model actions so that the absence of an anomaly is a condition for the success of the action. After the action is performed, the sensor can check whether an action was successful, and thus to determine whether an anomaly was determined by other types of reasoning - for example, can be used.

sections.heading: Related Work
sections.text: The current work is accomplished through planning, dynamic planning, abductive explanations, and subsequent action. Therefore, we are interested in other frameworks that have similar characteristics. There are many action theory frameworks and implementations that include incomplete knowledge, such as the Shanahan quota planning (2000), but these often assume complete knowledge of the world and have no semantics that extend to action capture.

sections.heading: Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text: We have formalized and implemented an online planning framework and demonstrated its application in a smart home environment. Error tolerance is achieved by deferring anomalies, which requires a formalism such as HPX to support capture along with postdiction. On the application side, work is currently underway to integrate the online approach of this paper into the general experimental cognitive robotics framework ExpCog (Listing 1; (Suchan and Bhatt 2012)).This integration will allow us to release the online planner so that it can be seamlessly applied to a wide range of robot control tasks and existing platforms such as ROS (http: / / www.ros.org).On the theoretical side, we are currently investigating domain-independent heuristics and their formalization in the sense of ASP to improve the overall performance of the planner: A huge corpus of heuristics in planning can be found in the PDL planning literature, but translated into the PASP planning literature.

MAPSIM (Brenner and Nebel 2009) is a continual planning framework based on the planning language MAPL. MAPL is similar to PDDL, but relies on a multi-valued logic. In MAPL, the not-knowing of the value of a certain fluent is modeled with a special unknown value. It is not possible to model conditional effects in MAPL, and hence postdiction is not possible. IndiGolog is a high-level programming language by De Giacomo and Levesque (1998) which has a search-operator that can also be used to perform planning.

metadata.abstractText: Making sense of incomplete and conflicting narrative knowledge in the presence of abnormalities, unobservable processes, and other real world considerations is a challenge and crucial requirement for cognitive robotics systems. An added challenge, even when suitably specialised action languages and reasoning systems exist, is practical integration and application within large-scale robot control frameworks. In the backdrop of an autonomous wheelchair robot control task, we report on application-driven work to realise postdiction triggered abnormality detection and re-planning for real-time robot control: (a) Narrative-based knowledge about the environment is obtained via a larger smart environment framework; and (b) abnormalities are postdicted from stablemodels of an answer-set program corresponding to the robot’s epistemic model. The overall reasoning is performed in the context of an approximate epistemic action theory based planner implemented via a translation to answer-set programming.
